title: How many U.S. senators will vote to convict former President Donald Trump of incitement of insurrection?
preds: Looks like the results are in 57-43. 7 Republicans crossed party lines to vote for former President Trump's conviction. https://www.cnn.com/politics/live-news/trump-impeachment-trial-02-13-2021/
Well @Chrisp , Cassidy did vote guilty after all.
What a historic event for all to witness, regardless of the vote.  I'll likely never again, as I have never before today, witness such a pivotal moment in history.  God Bless America.

Senators Toomey and Cassidy, who are/were the possible Republican yesses, voted no this morning to the question of witnesses. You can't really count Lindsay Graham's yea because his purpose was to slow the Senate down with a whole bunch of witnesses for the defense (bringing in Hillary Clinton, Hunter Biden, etc.)  That gets me to an expected vote of 54-46.  I expect Romney, Murkowski, Sasse and Collins to be yes on conviction.
Democrats have had 3 votes on this - all a 55-45.   I don't see that changing.

And so ends the global view  of America as a free and democratic nation. Trump failed in his insurrection bid but Republicans are taking the view since it failed no harm done. Party politics at is worst. This inaction to address home grown terrorism  will come back to haunt the US. . In what global forum will the US have the moral authority to lecture any nation on how it should conduct itself.
Well, Senator Cassidy didn't get much of an answer yesterday from defense lawyers about the call Trump had with Tuberville.  Not sure how he feels about that but going to split my vote here.
McConnel has signaled he'll vote no. So that's one less on the table. Graham switched vote to yes to allow witnesses, for a total of 55.
Only five agreed to witnesses. Pulling back from 56.
I had a friend tell me the other day, "common  sense  is not common "

55 - 45 vote of the Senate to call witness. Lindsey Graham (R,SC) remarkably switched his vote last minute to "aye", but this could mean that Rep plea will also call for own witnesses.
The process will be slowed down significantly, final conviction vote could happen as late as in March, as of now.

https://www.google.co.uk/amp/s/www.politico.com/amp/news/2021/02/12/republicans-weighting-conviction-trump-impeachment-468862 This feels accurate based on the constitutionality vote. Drawing the line between 55 and 56 makes it tough around those buckets. However with the final constitutionality vote reaching 56 feels like that needs to be the point estimate and it seems to skew up from there given the article. That said, you can argue it is constitutional but not impeach and could lose 1 of those to “why bother”. That said for at the very least Collins, Murkowski and Romney there seems to be little downside in impeaching, while Toomey retiring takes the pressure off him. Sasse and Cassidy may get cold feet, but to an extent they have already risked the primary challenge. I have significantly more in the tail than consensus. That is probably a delayed vote and more evidence coming out but at this stage I do not think we should ignore that.

At this point this seems largely a guessing game involving question choices two and three (above).   Reports of Trump continuing to 'bash' Mike Pence even as he was evacuated + close to danger (from rioters) may yet gain some (more) influence (with possibly an "on-the-fence" Republican or two). https://www.politico.com/news/2021/02/12/republicans-weighting-conviction-trump-impeachment-468862 https://www.npr.org/sections/trump-impeachment-trial-live-updates/2021/02/12/967517591/republicans-seek-clarity-on-what-trump-knew-about-pences-safety https://www.predictit.org/markets/detail/7054/How-many-Senators-will-vote-to-convict-Donald-Trump-on-incitement-by-Apr-29
My optimism is waning as party fealty reigns.

Senator Cassidy's perhaps not so accidental displaying to news photographers of his draft speech acquitting the former president means the likelihood of 51 to 55 votes for conviction increases strongly, in my view.[1]  I agree with @incognito that McConnell is not likely in play either as a "yes" vote.  He must be well aware of current polling showing that 69% of Republican voters say that are unlikely to vote for a candidate for the House or Senate who has voted to impeach or convict the former president.[2]  McConnell's primary concerns are getting corporate donors back to extract the hundreds of millions of dollars he needs to run the 2022 senate campaigns without alienating the former president's base. [1] https://www.washingtonpost.com/powerpost/impeachment-trump-republicans-cassidy/2021/02/12/6e0ec77a-6d73-11eb-9ead-673168d5b874_story.html
[2] https://www.vox.com/2021/2/10/22276210/trump-impeachment-trial-poll

The news source below indicates that Senator McConnell and Senator Cassidy are both leaning toward acquittal.   Senator Cassidy was 1 of the 6 Republicans that voted for a trial.  If Senator Cassidy is removed and all of the remaining Republicans who voted for a trial vote to convict President Trump, that is only 55 votes.  The number of 55 also assumes that the 50 Democrats in the Senate vote to convict President Trump, which seems incredibly likely at this point.  As a result, the number should be between 51 and 55.  https://www.politico.com/news/2021/02/12/republicans-weighting-conviction-trump-impeachment-468862

With photo of Cassidy's acquittal statement, I think this tilts things toward 51-55: https://twitter.com/jabinbotsford/status/1360329711889612804/photo/1 Mitt Romney's question indicates he is a virtual lock to vote yea.

Does anyone actually watching the trial consider that one side or the other are either beating expectations or underperforming in the quality of their arguments? I've developed a food intolerance to domestic American politics so I can't watch

Trump is the ultimate political prospecting at this point. Mitch is pump-faking the media as per usual, and saying "do your own thing."
Burr, Toomey, Portman and Shelby are on their way out. Who knows how they'll behave. Presumably they have kids that live in major metros (just a hunch.) Johnson, Cassidy and Young are worth watching. https://ballotpedia.org/United_States_Senate_elections,_2022
https://www.cnn.com/2021/02/09/politics/six-republicans-vote-impeachment-trial/index.html

Many of my fellow Republicans aren't even bothering to show up.  Perhaps they have appointments to get a spine transplant, but alas, probably not. However, a few of the Trumpeter Swains who cast their preposterous votes not to allow the trial at all might vote to convict.   Next time they run, someone might ask them if a crime boss who had exempt from prosecution for crimes he committed during his working life, but it's too late to save themselves from that line of questioning.  Instead, it might be worthwhile to look at which of these clowns might like to run in '24 without the looming prospect of M. Petits-Doigts.  If they were pretty sure there were enough of them, they might feel good about estopping him from coming back. On the other hand, most of them are still reduced to jelly by the fear that they might have to display some courage, so maybe not.  It is sad to recall that Nixon--whose crimes were much milder, whose positive achievements were more notable and enduring, and whose public decorum was almost painful--resigned because he knew he'd be convicted in the Senate.  My party's soul is not shriven, just shriveled.  If the Democrats were smart--an eventuality for which no evidence provides support--there wouldn't be a Republican officeholder outside the old Confederacy for a generation.

We found out 15 R Senators sat out Wednesday's proceedings altogether. I originally suggested that 8 of the remaining 43 would very likely not convict. I'm going to up that to a total of 15 given this info. We already figured it to be the case, but if they're willing to sit out altogether, seems to me they've made up their minds. That leaves 28 potentially in play, and 5-6 to get to 56, 10-12 to get to 62...nearly 50% of the "in play" Rs. That pushes me lower on the 56-61 and 62-66 (not to mention 67).  There was one note this morning in the news, that Nikki Haley came out publicly and distanced herself, and tried to distance the Republican party, from Trump. Perhaps a minor point, but I'm finely attuned to trying to find the pebble that begins the avalanche. The party *has* to know that they can't remain beholden to Trump forever, even if it helps them in the near-term. Then again, if they think they can finesse the vote and survive, they probably will.
(no change) Interesting update to one of @Rad4Caster post yesterday. If DT happens to see what Nikki Haley opined, would it unleash a flood of anger and pushback?

The Senate, like the nation, remains strongly divided along party lines.  The measure last week introduced by Senator Rand Paul, regarding  constitutionally of the impeachment process, failed 45-55.  A more formal measure this week regarding the same question passed, 56-44.  There are currently 50 democratic Senators and 50 Republican Senators.  As of this week, it appears there are only now 56 Senators who even believe the proceedings are constitutional, including 6 Republican and all 50 Democrat Senators.  It seems the most likely scenario is that all 50 Democrats and 5 or less of the 6 Republicans will vote to convict.  This is based on recent comments made this week.
This article is helpful to see where the senators stand https://www.usatoday.com/in-depth/news/politics/2021/02/09/where-all-100-senators-stand-second-donald-trump-impeachment-trial/4405437001/
The 97% is because I think a few more R’s will realize the gravity of the situation and vote their conscience. The 3% is just wishful thinking.

In all likelihood the entire Democratic senatorial caucus will vote to impeach (50), and the news / rhetoric from a select few Republican senators (i.e. Romney) suggest that they are willing to reach across the aisle and side with the Dems. I see a high likelihood of a handful of seasoned Republicans heading the call but my assumption as always is most (especially junior Senators) will stick to party lines. I put the most probability around 51-53 votes in favour of impeachment with a 50 vote count to be the next best option.

It is expected that all 50 Democratic senators will vote to convict Donald J. Trump. Additionally, 5 GOP senators voted that the trial was constitutional. It seems likely that those 5 GOP senators will vote to convict Donald J. Trump, which means that only 1 additional GOP senator would need to vote to convict. There are 10 GOP senators that have not put out a statement on if they will, or won't, convict Donald J. Trump [1]. It seems likely that at least one of Mitch McConnel, Rob Portman, or Daniel Sullivan will vote to convict, but unlikely that all 10 will vote to convict.  Thus, I predict, with a 100% probability, that between 56 and 61 senators will vote to convict Donald J. Trump. [1] https://www.usatoday.com/in-depth/news/politics/2021/02/09/where-all-100-senators-stand-second-donald-trump-impeachment-trial/4405437001/
I think they will keep all the Senators who voted that the trial is constitutional, but it is unlikely that the prosecution will pick up a significant additional number of votes.

the 6th GOP senator flipped on the issue of whether to try or not. does not mean he will convinct. his change was a surprise and given that getting 17 GOP votes is highly unlikely he may well go back in to the fold. Alternatively, his head is already above the parapit.

Same forecast, but adding here that CNN just noted that of 9 "undecided/unknown" R Senators (no idea how they decided they were "undecided/unknown), only 2 are likely running for election next year...not a definitive piece of data either way, but interesting that for at least 7 of them, they won't have to face voters for at least a couple of years. In fact, they just said only 16 are likely running for reelection next year...again, interesting piece of data.

I assumed the following probabilities of conviction by Senator: Romney, Sasse and Murkowski all at 100%. Collins, Toomey and Cassidy (the remaining people who voted for impeachment) at 80% each. Portman, Young, MCConnel, and Crapo each with a 5% chance. I then simulated assuming a 50% cross correlation in their votes and ran a few thousand simulations using correlated random variables. By the way, even assuming 0% for all the senators outside the top 6 still gets you something close to 60% odds of 56-61.  The inputs informing this analysis are here. Good piece on washington post showing most likely to vote for impeachment: https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2021/02/10/why-conviction-trumps-second-impeachment-trial-is-so-unlikely/
Comments from  republicans who voted for it: https://www.vox.com/22272229/senate-republicans-impeachment

Safe bet right now is 56-61. The 50 Dems are going to vote to convict, that much is certain. Mitt Romney is an almost sure bet as well, so it's gotta be at lest 51. Based on the vote that the impeachment was constitutional, we *might* expect 5 more Rs to jump on board. If so, that would get us to 56. Mitch McConnell is cagey - he's made a point of telling Senators to vote their conscience. He might be one more that we could add to the total, believe it or not, which would put us at 57.  That leaves 43 outstanding. It's fairly widely believed that the rest of the Rs are out - that their desire to get re-elected will outweigh any chance of voting to convict, no matter how convincing the argument is to impeach (the former president's base still holds pretty big sway). For 8 of the 43, it seems to me to be a 100% done deal that they won't vote to convict - they voted against certifying the election in the first place. That leaves 35. If we count the 56-57 above as sure things (admittedly, they're not), what are the chances that another 5-6 jump on board and put us over the 62 mark? Seems pretty unlikely, right? They're trading (at least in their minds) the power of their position as Senators for this one tiny, mostly meaningless vote, right?  What about to get to over the next hurdle? That'd take another 5-6, right (depending on whether we started with 56 or 57)? So that'd be a total of 10-12 out of 35, or 29-34% of the remaining "in play" Rs, nearly a third. Seems like a lot given the state of the rhetoric. Seems like a whole lot. If the vote happened today, I don't see either scenario playing out. Here's what might change my calculations: Trump coming out and saying something disastrous that the Rs can't ignore (and giving them an excuse to vote to convict) or a single powerful, or small group of less powerful, R Senators coming out publicly and providing cover. Not sure either of those will happen either. Side note: I assume all of the betweens have an implied "(inclusive)" after them.

There will be few fairly predictable Republican senators who will vote to convict. That gets to 55. But Republicans who would join the majority will try to create a group to make the jump together - safety in numbers. One way to look at the constitutional argument is to avoid dealing with the trial facts. If they decide the charges have a basis, the hesitant Trumpers might band together to flip the balance on this issue.
Think in the unlikely event they convict, it will be due to an agreement among Republicans to go in together. In poker terms, they will fold or raise but not call.

I agree with @mwackers, @024_andrew, and @terry-smith that the key is whether Senator Cassidy (LA) will vote to acquit after taking a courageous stand to vote for the constitutionality of the trial.  The other five Republican senators seem to have made strong comments in the days and weeks after January 6 about the former president's culpability for inciting insurrection, the one exception being Senator Collins.  Collins has a history of expressing "concern" while ultimately falling in line with the party.  I am assuming the other four will follow through and vote guilty. Cassidy has been careful in his public statements to say his vote for the constitutionality of the trial would not automatically or necessarily lead to his vote to convict the former president.  It would not surprise me at all that someone who styles himself as a "constitutional conservative" [1] would uphold the legality of the proceedings while acquitting on the substance or in line with his party or constituent sentiment.  Cassidy voted with the former president 89% of the time.[2] Given Collins's history and Cassidy's unpredictable emergence as a gettable vote, I am weighting the balance of probability between 51 and 55 votes to convict, but I am also leaving a large percentage between 56 and 61. [1] https://www.politico.com/news/2021/02/10/bill-cassidy-defends-impeachment-vote-468505
[2] https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/congress-trump-score/bill-cassidy/
I think  Cassidy is going to stand up to his constituents.

The vote to impeach former President Trump totaled 56-44 with 6 Republican senators voting for impeachment. The threshold to convict President Trump is higher than to impeach him, 17 Republicans will need to vote in favor of conviction. So it is fair to say that these numbers will hold or be between 51 and 55. These six individuals (see article below) are potentially the ones to vote to convict President Trump. However, with the backlash that Senator Cassidy received, it is likely that he will not convict President Trump, which leaves the vote at 55-45. https://thehill.com/homenews/senate/538386-the-gop-senators-likely-to-vote-for-trumps-conviction
I believe some Republicans will vote for conviction but probably not enough to convict.

Six Republicans voted that the trial was constitutional. Even though the constitutionality of the trial is a separate issue from the case itself this is clearly a political trial and not a legal one. We can reasonably expect those same six Republican senators to vote for impeachment.

Just going to quote @mwackers https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1231429
56 possible.  But there has always been more support for Trump that expected so still this bin 2 most likely.
Agree with @Bobbiekar52 that it would be interesting to see what would happen if it was a secret vote.
Here we go... can't wait for tomorrow's arguments!

There is still a chance that Republicans will realize that dumping Trump is in their best interest, although is it highly unlikely. If at least 10 republicans impeach, it would be a significant outcome.
Only 56 voted to move forward with the trial, so seems unlikely that more than that would vote to convict: https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2021/02/09/trump-impeachment-live-updates/

The US Senate is 50 Democrat and 50 Republican, for the purpose of this forecast I will assume that every 50 Democratic Senators votes to convict, leaving only the Republican Senators to consider ->
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_current_United_States_senators In Trump's first Senate Trial, Mitt Romney became the first senator in history to be from the president's party and voting to convict that president ->
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_impeachment_of_Donald_Trump I will assume he does so again for Trump's Second Senate Trial. Recently there was a senate vote over the constitutionality of the Trump Second Senate Trial, with 45 Republicans saying shouldn't go ahead ->
https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2021/jan/26/trump-impeachment-republicans-senate-vote-to-dismiss I believe that these 5 Republican Senators, including Romney described as "longtime Trump critics" who voted with Democrats are the only Republican Senators willing to consider voting to convict. I can't realistically see a Republican Senator voting to convict in a trial they previously voted shouldn't even be taking place. Therefore I believe that the most likely outcomes are 51-55 = 85%, followed by the 56-61=15%.
Unlikely to be impeached given that all but a handful of Republicans thought it unconstitutional. I can see another 5 or so Republicans being swayed, More than that is unlikely but possible.

Democrats with 50 votes plus
1) Collins- Likely
2) Romney- Likely
3) Murkowski- Likely
4) Toomey- Likely and not running again, so no re-election posturing
5) Sasse- Likely
6) Cassidy- maybe- https://www.c-span.org/video/?508891-5/senator-cassidy-video-evidence-shown-impeachment-trial 56 Votes is very possilbe along with at least one vote from the following (ranked roughly by likeliest to convict): 7) Shelby- maybe  but not running again, so no re-election posturing
8) Portman- unlikely but not running again so no re-election posturing
9) Burr- Very unlikely but not running again so no re-election posturing
10) Sullivan- unlikely (2026)
11) Risch- unlikely (2026)
12) Grassley- Very unlikely, but there is speculation he may not run again, could he be swayed? (2022)
13) Johnson- Very unlikely, but there is speculation he may not run again, could he be swayed? (2022)
14) Crapo- unlikely (2022)
15) Young- unlikely (2022)
16) McConnell- unlikely, would likely loose his leadership position if he voted to convict Unlikely to go beyond 66. Wildcard- Thune (2022)- very unlikely, holds leadership post that would be at risk if he voted to convict.
https://kscj.com/2021/02/09/thune-receives-pushback-from-some-in-g-o-p/
www.cnbc.com/amp/2021/02/10/trump-impeachment-trial-day-2-live-updates-video.html
56 voted constitutional.  I can’t help but wonder (as I did with the first trial) what the vote would be if it was written secret ballot.

I start with 56 as the most likely floor, since that was the total on Tuesday about whether it was constitutional for the Senate to hold the conviction vote: https://www.senate.gov/legislative/LIS/roll_call_lists/roll_call_vote_cfm.cfm?congress=117&session=1&vote=00057 It seems unlikely that someone like Bill Cassidy would say, "Yeah I thought it was constitutional, but Trump won on the merits"... but given the firestorm of criticism he is getting, he could very well vote no.  It's extremely unlikely that this would go into into the 60s, because most GOP senators don't want to stick their necks out and have to deal with primary challengers, etc.

Romney against Trump
Sasse against Doesn't face re-election till 2027
Murkowski Against
Toomey against Not running for Relection 
Collinns In favor Doesn't face re-election till 2027
Cassidy in favor  Doesn't face re-election till 2027 This hinges on Cassidy, Collins, and no further defections. 
Conversely, it also depends on a bumbling defense.  A sterling defense should bring home all republican senators, and no abstentions.

6 republicans voted trial is constitutional. So i doubt more than 6 would vote to convict. Of course 55 is the bucket border! Collins and Murkowski will vote to convict. Sasse, Romny and Toomey will probably vote to convict.So more than 51 senators.  I am not sure about Cassidy for Louisiana.
Initial forecast. GOP profiles in courage. This won't be like the 2018 pandemic that collective memory erased. YMMV

..Using the 56-senator vote for constitutionality of the impeaching a former president as a rough benchmark for starters. (https://time.com/5937757/impeachment-trial-constitutional-vote/) FWIW, I believe that there are currently 48 Senators who ID as Democrats plus two Independents, who usually caucus with the Dems. (https://ballotpedia.org/List_of_current_members_of_the_U.S._Congress) https://www.vox.com/22272229/senate-republicans-impeachment https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2021/01/25/us/politics/senate-impeachment-whip-count.html
SO GLAD SOMEONE ADDED THIS QUESTION! intial bet. this one will be so fun to watch.
55 voted for the procedural motions like constitutionally.  I suspect those are yes votes to convince.  for me the question is whether they will gain votes in the presentations.
